title: How your muscular system works - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the body's weight is comprised of skeletal muscles?
Which of the following is NOT governed by the muscular system?

options.label: A
options.text: Sperm cells and hair-like cilia in our airways

options.label: C
options.text: White blood cells and cardiac muscles

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the stapedius muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: To attach the cheek to the teeth

options.label: B
options.text: To generate most of the body's motion

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain posture by holding the head upright

options.label: D
options.text: To transmit sound vibrations to the inner ear

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers?

options.label: A
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers are endurance cells, while slow-twitch fibers react instantly when triggered

options.label: B
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers react instantly when triggered but quickly use up their energy and tire out, while slow-twitch fibers are endurance cells

options.label: C
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers are found in the heart, while slow-twitch fibers are found in the skeletal muscles

options.label: D
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers are found in the smooth muscles, while slow-twitch fibers are found in the skeletal muscles

multiple-choice.question: Which type of muscle contraction creates a stabilizing force without changing the length of the muscle fibers?
What is the main function of the autonomic nervous system in relation to the muscular system?

options.label: A
options.text: To give us complete control over the movements of the skeletal muscles

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the heart rate and blood pressure

options.label: C
options.text: To manage the body's cardiac and smooth muscles beyond our direct control

options.label: D
options.text: To refine our motions even further by controlling the fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the muscular system in maintaining the body's temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces about 85% of the body's heat, which is then spread evenly across the body via the blood

options.label: B
options.text: It produces about 15% of the body's heat, which is then spread unevenly across the body

options.label: C
options.text: It produces no heat, and the body's temperature is maintained by other systems

options.label: D
options.text: It produces heat, but it is not necessary for the body's survival

multiple-choice.question: Which type of muscles are connected to the somatic nervous system?
What is the main function of the cardiac muscle in the muscular system?

options.label: A
options.text: To generate most of the body's motion

options.label: B
options.text: To pump blood throughout the body

options.label: D
options.text: To manage the body's cardiac and smooth muscles beyond our direct control

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the muscular system in everyday life?

options.label: A
options.text: It is largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost everything we do

options.label: B
options.text: It is responsible for generating most of the body's motion

options.label: C
options.text: It is necessary for the body's survival, but it is not visible

options.label: D
options.text: It is not necessary for the body's survival

title: The strange case of the cyclops sheep - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: In the 1950s, what unusual phenomenon was observed in sheep on ranches in Idaho?

options.label: A
options.text: The sheep were giving birth to lambs with two heads.

options.label: B
options.text: The sheep were giving birth to lambs with a singular deformity, specifically one eye.

options.label: C
options.text: The sheep were not producing enough milk.

options.label: D
options.text: The sheep were dying at a young age.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the active molecule found in wild corn lilies that caused the defect in the sheep?
Which gene, when mutated, produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog in fruit flies?
What was the effect of turning off the hedgehog genes in mice, as observed by Professor Philip Beachy's lab?

options.label: A
options.text: They developed severe defects in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: They developed no defects at all.

options.label: C
options.text: They developed mild defects in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: They died at a young age.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the hedgehog protein in normal healthy development?

options.label: A
options.text: It tells cells to release a protein called smoothened.

options.label: B
options.text: It inhibits the protein patched, allowing smoothened to freely signal the cells.

options.label: C
options.text: It blocks the protein smoothened from sending signals.

options.label: D
options.text: It activates the protein patched, preventing smoothened from signaling the cells.

multiple-choice.question: How does cyclopamine affect the smoothened protein?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows smoothened to freely signal the cells.

options.label: B
options.text: It inhibits smoothened from sending signals.

options.label: C
options.text: It blocks smoothened from sending signals by binding to it.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on smoothened.

multiple-choice.question: What human syndrome is associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein?
What was the proposed use of cyclopamine's smoothened binding powers, as suggested by Professor Philip Beachy's team?

options.label: A
options.text: As a treatment for skin cancer

options.label: B
options.text: As a treatment for Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: As a treatment for other types of cancer

options.label: D
options.text: As a treatment for birth defects

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the researchers' attempts to use cyclopamine as a treatment for skin cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: It was successful and became a widely used treatment.

options.label: B
options.text: It was not successful and was abandoned.

options.label: C
options.text: It caused negative side effects and was difficult to work with, but led to the discovery of related molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no effect on skin cancer.

multiple-choice.question: What was the ultimate outcome of the discovery of cyclopamine and its effects on the hedgehog gene?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a better understanding of the hedgehog gene and its role in development.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the development of new treatments for skin cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the discovery of new molecules with smoothened binding powers.

multiple-choice.question: How did the scientists initially hypothesize that the pregnant ewes had been affected, leading to the birth of cyclops sheep?

options.label: A
options.text: They thought the ewes had been exposed to a virus.

options.label: B
options.text: They thought the ewes had eaten poisonous plants.

options.label: C
options.text: They thought the ewes had been affected by a genetic mutation.

options.label: D
options.text: They thought the ewes had been exposed to a chemical toxin.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the researchers' efforts to replicate the effect of the cyclops sheep in lab rats?

options.label: A
options.text: They were able to successfully replicate the effect.

options.label: B
options.text: They were unable to replicate the effect.

options.label: C
options.text: They found a different effect in the lab rats.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not attempt to replicate the effect in lab rats.

title: A brief history of banned numbers - Alessandra King

multiple-choice.question: In Ancient Greece, who is credited with finding numerical patterns in shapes, music, and the stars?
What type of numbers did Hippasus discover that challenged the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe?
According to legend, what was the punishment given to Hippasus for publicizing his findings on irrational numbers?
What was the key advantage of Hindu-Arabic numerals that made them useful for merchants and bankers in the Middle Ages?

options.label: A
options.text: They were easier to calculate with

options.label: B
options.text: They were more familiar to customers than to merchants

options.label: C
options.text: They included a symbol for zero, allowing for more efficient calculations

options.label: D
options.text: They were more complex than Roman numerals

multiple-choice.question: In what century did Florence ban the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping due to concerns about forgery and debt recording?
What was the primary reason for the controversy over zero and negative numbers in the Middle Ages?

options.label: A
options.text: They were considered easier to forge or alter

options.label: B
options.text: They were less familiar to customers than to merchants

options.label: C
options.text: They opened the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt, which was regarded with suspicion

multiple-choice.question: What type of numbers were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century?
Who avoided using zero, even though it would have made it easier to find solutions to cubic and quartic equations?
Why are some numbers potentially considered illegal?

options.label: C
options.text: They can represent protected information, such as copyrights or state secrets

multiple-choice.question: In what year did the idea of illegal numbers gain attention when code that could be used to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed in the form of a large prime number?

title: Are you a body with a mind or a mind with a body? - Maryam Alimardani

multiple-choice.question: Which philosopher argued that the existence of our mind and thoughts is the ultimate proof of our existence, even if our physical sensations are just a hallucinatory dream?
What is the primary effect of the rubber hand illusion experiment on the participant's perception?

options.label: A
options.text: The person starts to feel like the dummy hand is theirs

options.label: B
options.text: The person becomes confused about which hand is real

options.label: C
options.text: The person feels no sensation at all

options.label: D
options.text: The person starts to feel pain in the dummy hand

multiple-choice.question: According to René Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence?
Who, according to Nicolas Malebranche, is responsible for moving our hand when we think about reaching for a fork?
What do the rubber hand illusion experiment and similar virtual reality experiments suggest about the relationship between our bodies and external sensations?

options.label: B
options.text: They are deeply integrated and inseparable from our subjective consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: They are just a hallucinatory dream

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of mind uploading, as described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Transferring a human consciousness into a computer

options.label: B
options.text: Extending our sense of self to new wearable devices

options.label: C
options.text: Simulating a body capable of delivering physical sensations

options.label: D
options.text: Transferring human consciousness into a computer, potentially requiring simulating a body capable of delivering physical sensations

multiple-choice.question: Which philosopher argued that the material world is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions?
According to modern scientists, what is the relationship between the mind and body?

options.label: B
options.text: They are deeply integrated, with the body's physical senses and brain activity forming consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: They are just a hallucinatory dream

multiple-choice.question: What idea is shared by Buddhist thought and the writings of philosophers from Heidegger to Aristotle?

options.label: A
options.text: Our bodies are part of our consciousness and vice versa

options.label: B
options.text: Our minds and bodies are two separate things

options.label: C
options.text: Our senses can easily mislead us in our judgment of self

options.label: D
options.text: Our physical sensations are just a hallucinatory dream

multiple-choice.question: What is the open question regarding the nature of our self, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Is our self a mind equipped with a physical body?

options.label: B
options.text: Is our self a complex organism that's gained consciousness over millions of years of evolution?

options.label: C
options.text: Is our self something else entirely that no one's yet dreamt up?

options.label: D
options.text: The nature of our self remains an open question, encompassing multiple possibilities

options.label: B
options.text: Reliability refers to the consistency of test scores, while validity refers to the accuracy of test questions

options.label: C
options.text: Reliability refers to the consistency of test scores, while validity refers to the fairness of test questions

options.label: D
options.text: Reliability refers to the accuracy of test questions, while validity refers to the consistency of test scores

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Long-term life consequences and potential harm

options.label: A

title: How do executive orders work? - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What is an executive order, and how does it differ from a law?

options.label: A
options.text: An executive order is a law passed by Congress and signed by the President.

options.label: B
options.text: An executive order is a presidential decree that requires Congressional approval.

options.label: C
options.text: An executive order is a directive issued by the President without Congressional consultation or permission.

options.label: D
options.text: An executive order is a judicial review of a presidential decision.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process for passing a law in the United States, and how does it differ from issuing an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: A law is passed by the President, while an executive order is passed by Congress.

options.label: B
options.text: A law requires a majority vote in Congress and the President's signature, while an executive order is issued by the President without Congressional consultation.

options.label: C
options.text: A law is passed by the Supreme Court, while an executive order is passed by the President.

options.label: D
options.text: A law requires a unanimous vote in Congress, while an executive order requires a majority vote.

multiple-choice.question: What are some common reasons why a President might issue an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: To respond to an emergency or crisis situation.

options.label: B
options.text: To expand or contract the power of federal agencies.

options.label: C
options.text: To clarify and implement a policy.

multiple-choice.question: What are some notable examples of executive orders that have changed the course of American history?

options.label: A
options.text: FDR's establishment of the Works Progress Administration and Harry Truman's desegregation of the armed forces.

options.label: B
options.text: Lyndon Johnson's establishment of requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment.

options.label: C
options.text: FDR's executive order to intern Japanese-Americans during World War II.

multiple-choice.question: What are the checks and balances on the President's power to issue executive orders?

options.label: A
options.text: Congress can pass laws to counteract executive orders, and judges can halt them by deeming them unconstitutional.

options.label: B
options.text: The President has absolute power to issue executive orders without any checks or balances.

options.label: C
options.text: The Supreme Court has the final say on the constitutionality of executive orders.

options.label: D
options.text: The President can only issue executive orders with Congressional approval.

multiple-choice.question: How have executive orders been used throughout history, and what has been the trend in their use?

options.label: A
options.text: Executive orders have been used sparingly throughout history, with most Presidents issuing fewer than 100.

options.label: B
options.text: Executive orders have been used increasingly over time, with each President issuing roughly 300 since the 1960s.

options.label: C
options.text: Executive orders have been used primarily in times of crisis or emergency.

options.label: D
options.text: Executive orders have been used exclusively to expand the power of federal agencies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the courts in reviewing executive orders?

options.label: A
options.text: The courts have no power to review executive orders.

options.label: B
options.text: The courts can review executive orders and halt them if they are deemed unconstitutional.

options.label: C
options.text: The courts can only review executive orders in times of crisis or emergency.

options.label: D
options.text: The courts have the final say on the constitutionality of executive orders.

multiple-choice.question: How can a President's successor eliminate an executive order issued by their predecessor?

options.label: A
options.text: By issuing a new executive order that counteracts the previous one.

options.label: B
options.text: By passing a law through Congress that repeals the executive order.

options.label: C
options.text: By taking no action, as executive orders automatically expire after a certain period.

options.label: D
options.text: By seeking judicial review of the executive order.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the scale of the graph

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: The power of creative constraints - Brandon Rodriguez

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What term is used to describe the limitations and requirements that must be addressed to accomplish a goal?
**Comprehension**: What role do constraints play in the scientific process?

options.label: A
options.text: Constraints hinder scientific progress by limiting experimentation.

options.label: B
options.text: Constraints are irrelevant in science and only apply to engineering.

options.label: C
options.text: Constraints are essential in experimental design, helping scientists understand new phenomena.

options.label: D
options.text: Constraints are only relevant in certain scientific fields.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: A scientist wants to study a new virus but has limited resources. How can they use constraints to design an experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: Ignore the constraints and gather as much data as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Wait for more funding before starting the experiment.

options.label: C
options.text: Consider the available tools and techniques to design an experiment that maximizes resource utilization.

options.label: D
options.text: Try to gather data without considering the constraints.

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**: How did constraints contribute to a breakthrough in science?

options.label: A
options.text: The discovery of penicillin resulted from careful planning and experimentation.

options.label: B
options.text: The discovery of synthetic dye resulted from a well-funded research project.

options.label: C
options.text: The discovery of plastic resulted from a careful analysis of material properties.

options.label: D
options.text: The discovery of penicillin resulted from a happy accident that addressed the constraints of a different problem.

multiple-choice.question: **Synthesis**: How can understanding constraints guide scientific progress across multiple fields?

options.label: A
options.text: By ignoring constraints, scientists can make new discoveries.

options.label: B
options.text: By focusing on a single field, scientists can make discoveries with no relevance to other fields.

options.label: C
options.text: By working in isolation, scientists can make discoveries with no relevance to other fields.

options.label: D
options.text: By understanding constraints, scientists can make discoveries with applications in multiple fields.

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: Are constraints a hindrance to scientific progress?

options.label: B
options.text: No, constraints are essential to scientific progress.

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on the field of science.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the individual scientist.

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: Which Mars lander used an airbag system to land safely on the Martian surface?
**Comprehension**: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of creative freedom in scientific progress.

options.label: D
options.text: The role of constraints in scientific progress.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: A scientist wants to design a new water filtration system for astronauts on Mars. What constraints should they consider?

options.label: B
options.text: The availability of resources on Mars

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**: What can be inferred about the relationship between constraints and creativity?

options.label: A
options.text: Constraints limit creativity and hinder scientific progress.

options.label: B
options.text: Constraints are irrelevant to creativity and only apply to engineering.

options.label: C
options.text: Constraints can guide decision-making and ensure objectives are met.

options.label: D
options.text: Constraints are the boundaries of creativity, not the foundation of it.

multiple-choice.question: What significant achievement did scientists in Chicago accomplish during World War II that marked a milestone in nuclear energy?

options.text: They developed a method to enrich uranium.

multiple-choice.question: Why are most neutrons emitted from fission unable to be captured by uranium nuclei?

options.label: B
options.text: They have too much kinetic energy.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not scattered enough by the moderator.

options.label: D
options.text: They are absorbed by the control rods.

options.text: To increase the concentration of U-238.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the concentration of U-235.

options.label: C
options.text: To compensate for the low fission rate and maintain a chain reaction.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the risk of a nuclear meltdown.

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb heat from the fission products.

options.text: Nuclear meltdown, caused by a pipe break or pump failure.

options.label: B
options.text: Radioactive leak, caused by a containment failure.

options.label: C
options.text: Chain reaction, caused by excess neutrons.

options.label: D
options.text: Fuel enrichment, caused by centrifuge malfunction.

options.label: A
options.text: It must be stored in pools of water for a few years.

options.label: B
options.text: It must be isolated from the environment until it has safely decayed.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be reused as fuel.

options.label: D
options.text: It can be disposed of in landfills.

multiple-choice.question: What are the security risks associated with spent nuclear fuel?

options.label: A
options.text: It can sustain a chain reaction.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be mined to make bombs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of control rods in a nuclear reactor?

options.label: A
options.text: To capture excess neutrons and maintain a chain reaction.

options.label: B
options.text: To slow down neutrons and increase the fission rate.

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb heat from the fission products.

options.text: It is a renewable energy source.

options.label: B
options.text: It produces no greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: C
options.text: It generates a large amount of electricity from a small amount of fuel.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a low-cost source of energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is a major challenge in storing spent nuclear fuel for long periods?

options.label: C
options.text: The uncertainty about the long-term security of storage facilities.

multiple-choice.question: Why are sloths a great habitat for other organisms?

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have a slow metabolism and provide a stable environment
